School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Weijin Road 92 Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract Plasma has been widely used in wastewater treatment, material modification and biomedicine due to its unique properties. In this work, a coaxial cylindrical dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor was set up to investigate the effects of electrode materials and catalyst combined with DBD plasma on CO2 decomposition under room temperature and atmosphere pressure. The materials of inner electrode and outer electrode were investigated without catalysts packed in the reactor. It was found that the aluminum rod as inner electrode performed better than copper rod and stainless steel rod due to the moderate thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity of aluminum rod. Nevertheless, copper foil worked better as external electrode material since its higher electrical conductivity facilitated generation of high energy electrons by the high voltage between electrodes. After perovskite-type catalyst was introduced in the reactor, CO2 conversion increased, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of perovskite combined with plasma discharge. Perovskite-type catalysts could modulate the capacitance of the reactor to make plasma discharge more uniform and increased CO2 conversion, while plasma discharge provided high energy electrons that activated oxides sites and basic sites of perovskite-type catalysts. The maximum CO2 conversion was 23 % and maximum energy efficiency was 2.1 % when MgTiO3 was packed in the reactor. Keywords Dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma Electrode materials Perovskites Synergistic effect CO2 decomposition 1 Introduction Since the first industrial revolution in the 1750s, the massive combustion of fossil fuels has speeded up the development of human industrial civilization, yet coming with a dramatic increase of CO2 into the atmosphere. From 1960 to 2016, the content of CO2 in the atmosphere increased by 62.1 % because of a large amount of consumption of carbon resources [1]. Even COVID-19 caused a global pandemic in the spring of 2020 and many factories were shut down, and there was still a growing tendency of the CO2 content. The high concentration of CO2 has raised a series of problems, such as extreme weather, global warming and so on [2], which has affected the sustainable development of industry and even threaten the survival of human beings [3]. More than 170 nations, who committed to fight climate change by cutting carbon emissions and signed the Paris Agreement in 2016 [4]. Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage (CCUS) can sequester CO2 and transform CO2 to high value-added products [5,6], such as hydrocarbons, acids, alcohols and so on [7–10]. In recent years, some CO2 utilization routes have shown broad prospects for application, which could greatly reduce CO2 emissions and effectively alleviate the predicament of dwindling resource [11]. Among these routes, the decomposition of CO2 into CO is of great importance since the produced CO is far more active than CO2 and can be easily fixed into industrial raw materials [12,13]. Therefore, CO2 decomposition reaction has attracted a lot of attention. CO2 molecule has a highly symmetric structure with very high dissociation energy 5.5 eV [14]. Through traditional thermal catalytic method, the splitting from CO2 to CO occurred at high temperature [15], which greatly limits its industrial application due to high energy input. In recent years, electrocatalysis [16], photocatalysis [17], and other transformation pathways have been reported to promote CO2 decomposition at lower temperature than thermal catalysis. Comparatively, plasma discharge showed a great competitiveness for catalytic decomposition of CO2 since high-energy electrons in plasma could directly decompose CO2 at room temperature and ambient pressure. Non-thermal plasma (NTP) is kind of ionized gaseous substance, which includes free radicals, high-energy electrons and various ions. The electronic temperature can reach tens thousands of degrees while the apparent temperature is kept at room temperature [18]. NTP technology has been widely used in wastewater treatment and poisonous gas purification [19], materials modification [20], biomedicine and other fields with its characteristic high-energy and low temperature [21]. NTP could be classified by energy intensity and type of plasma discharge as microwave discharge [22], gliding arc discharge [23], corona discharge [24], glow discharge [25], dielectric barrier discharge [14,22,24,26–36], and pulse discharge [34,36]. Among them, decomposition of CO2 by dielectric barrier discharge has a promising application since it is easy to be achieved either in laboratory or industrial production [37]. Most investigations about CO2 decomposition in dielectric barrier discharge reactor mainly focused on reactor parameters and packing materials to improve CO2 conversion and energy efficiency [27]. Xu et al. found that the mixture of argon or nitrogen (80 %) with CO2(20 %) can increase CO2 conversion a lot [32]. However, the actual amount of converted CO2 decreased and more energy was needed for separation CO from the products since the byproducts of O3 and NxOx were generated. Michielsen et al. studied the synergistic effect of catalysis-plasma on the decomposition of CO2 and found that the conversion with BaTiO3 catalysts was twice as much as that in the empty reactor [29]. And some theoretical investigations help us to a further understand the principle of decomposition CO2 to CO and O2 in DBD reactor, such as the collision mechanism [35], level-lumping method and reaction kinetics model [14,33]. According to the collision theory, only a few electrons could be directly involved in reaction while most of electrons will be converted to heat and the upper limit of energy efficiency for CO2 decomposition was 5 % [14]. Uytdenhouwen et al. proposed the concept of partial chemical equilibrium to evaluate the effects of plasma processing parameters, packing materials and the potential effect of plasma-catalysis [30]. They found that no apparent synergistic effect between plasma and catalyst was observed. We deduced that the potential synergistic effect of catalyst and plasma may vary with the catalyst type and need to further investigated. In this work, the effect of electrode materials, discharge power, CO2 flow of rate, perovskite-type materials and so on were investigated in the plasma reactors to study CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. The synergistic effect of perovskite-plasma was studied based on CO2 decomposition performance in a cylindrical plasma reactor through characterization including XRD, TEM, SEM, CO2-TPD and BET. 2 Experiment 2.1 Experimental set-up The reaction was performed in a cylindrical dielectric barrier reactor. The experimental schematic diagram was shown in Fig. 1 , which mainly includes three parts: (i) dielectric barrier plasma reactor, (ii) on-line detection analytical system, containing gas chromatography, oscilloscope and computer, (iii) gas circuit and wires. The reactor is a quartz tube with 16 mm outer diameter and 13 mm inner diameter as shown Fig. 2 . The DBD reactor was supplied by an AC high voltage power (Suman, CTP-2000 K), meanwhile, the electrical signals were continuously recorded by an oscilloscope (Tektronix, DOP-2012B) with a high voltage probe (Tektronix, P6015A) and a current transformer (Tektronix, P622). 2.2 Packing materials MgTiO3, CaTiO3, SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 were synthesized with metallic oxide or inorganic metal salts mixed with TiO2 through the molten salt method [38]. The specific synthesis parameters are shown in Table 1 . A small amount of KCl was added to strengthen the fusion of molten salt in the calcination process, then the sample was washed 5 times with hot water (60 °C) to remove residual KCl. In the end, the sample was dried at 100 °C for 6 h in an oven. 2.3 Test of reaction performance The gas from the reactor outlet was detected through an online gas chromatograph (Agilent, 4890D) in the process of decomposition of CO2. In general, the absolute quantity method Eq. (1) is used to calculate the conversion of CO2. Here, we adopted the relative quantity method Eq. (2) since the product contains CO2, CO and O2. The carbon balance was within ±2 %, which indicates the feasibility of the above method. By this method, the trouble of measuring the outlet flow rate could be saved while ensure the calculation accurate. In the discharge process, Specific Energy Input (SEI) is proportional to the discharge power and inversely proportional to CO2 flow rate, which represents the energy input per unit CO2 volume. The reaction enthalpies of decomposition CO2 is ΔH (279.8 kJ/mol). When plasma processing in an empty reactor, residence time would be the main factor that affected the conversion of CO2 decomposition. The electrode materials, reactor size and reactor materials have been demonstrated to crucially affect CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. As shown in Fig. 3, the conversion of CO2 decreases along with the increase of the CO2 flow rate when other parameters were kept unchanged. At CO2 flow rate 20 mL/min, CO2 conversion with aluminum rod electrode was higher than those with copper rod and stainless steel rod by 3 % and 2.6 % respectively. With the increase of CO2 flow rate, CO2 conversion decreased. In general, CO2 conversion with the aluminum rod as electrode material was obviously higher than that with the stainless steel rod and the copper rod, which is associated with the effect of thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity. On one hand, the material with higher electrical conductivity could release more high-energy electrons and then produce more reactive species, which leads to a higher CO2 conversion. The electrical conductivity of copper (5.96 × 107 s cm−1) is higher than that of aluminum (3.5 × 107 s cm−1) and stainless steel (1 × 107 s cm−1). On the other hand, the thermal conductivity of copper (386 W m−1 °C−1) is higher than that of aluminum (203.5 W m−1 °C−1) and stainless steel (16.2 W m−1 °C−1). A higher thermal conductivity would result in higher temperature on inner electrode, which would use more energy for heat that would weaken the positive effect of a higher electrical conductivity on CO2 decomposition. In addition, an infrared Hand-Held Thermometer was used to detect the temperature during process of reaction and the results indicated that the temperature of the copper rod was 11 ± 1 °C higher than the aluminum rod when the discharge process is stabilized. As a result, aluminum rod obtained a better performance in CO2 decomposition because of a moderate thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity. More percentage of input energy was used to generate high energy electrons not to heating, which led to a higher CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. As shown in Fig. 4 , the energy efficiency increased as CO2 flow rate increased from 20 mL/min to 100 mL/min. Apparently, energy efficiency is affected by both CO2 flow rate and conversion. In fact, energy efficiency is also affected by the plasma reactor parameters including electrode material, length of outer electrode and catalyst. The energy efficiency in the empty reactor with an aluminum rod as the inner electrode increases 2.4 times when increasing the feed flow rate from 20 mL/min to 100 mL/min. In general, the energy efficiency in this work is ranging from 1 to 4 that is varied with the catalyst and plasma condition (Figs. 4, 6, 8, 9, 10), which is lower than the reported upper limit of energy efficiency 5 % for CO2 decomposition [14]. 3.1.2 Effect of outer electrode material on CO2 decomposition Figs. 5 and 6 show the effect of reactor with different outer electrode materials on CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. With the feed flow rate increasing, the CO2 conversion showed a trend of decline when other parameters were constant. The conversion of reactor with copper foil was 13.41 %, aluminum foil got 10.9 % and stainless-steel mesh obtained 9.36 % at feed flow rate of 20 mL/min. In addition, CO2 conversion of reactor with copper foil and aluminum foil were roughly similar with each other, which were 1.2 times than that of stainless steel mesh under the feed flow rate of 100 mL/min. We have pointed out that copper has a higher electrical conductivity, so copper was easier to generate high-energy electrons in plasma reactor. Unlike the inner electrode, the outer electrode was totally exposed to air so that the accumulated heat inside the reactor can be released away faster from outer electrode than from inner electrode. Therefore, copper foil performed better than aluminum foil and stainless steel mesh. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the tendency of CO2 energy efficiency with stainless steel mesh as outer electrode doesn’t agree with copper foil and aluminum foil because of a lower CO2 conversion. 3.2 Effect of catalyst and discharge power on CO2 decomposition 3.2.1 Effect of perovskite-type catalyst on CO2 decomposition The synergistic effects of the perovskite-type materials (MgTiO3, CaTiO3, SrTiO3, BaTiO3) and plasma discharge to the conversion and energy efficiency of CO2 decomposition is shown in Figs. 7 and 8. The reactor with MgTiO3 packed had higher conversion of CO2 than empty reactor by 4 % and the conversion of reactor with CaTiO3 packed was similar with empty reactor under feed flow rate of 20 mL/min. Meanwhile, the conversion of empty reactor and packing CaTiO3 almost equally as ever and still lower than that of MgTiO3 by 0.9 % at the feed flow rate of 100 mL/min. The conversion of reactor with MgTiO3 packed decreased from 14.1 %–4.9 % and the conversion of empty reactor decreased from 10.1 % to 4.0 % when the CO2 feed flow rate increased from 20 mL/min to 100 mL/min. The whole reaction system would be changed when catalyst packed in the reactor because the catalyst as an filling medium would change the capacitance of reactor firstly and adjust the discharge characteristics of reactor [26,28]. This was the most intuitive performance of physical character that affected CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. Additionally, the physical structure of the catalyst would affect the reaction process by effective pore structure and surface area, which could help increasing the residence time of CO2. What’s more, the adsorption of CO2 at basic sites would change intermediate state that contained carbon species. High-energy particles in the plasma reactor activated the oxide sites and basic sites at lower temperature. As a result, the change of capacitance and activation mechanism consisted of the synergistic effect to the conversion and energy efficiency of CO2 decomposition. 3.2.2 Packing MgTiO3 with different sizes As we know, perovskite-type materials have a larger dielectric constant, that is a vital factor to change plasma discharge characteristic. The size of perovskite was investigated when MgTiO3 packed in the reactor as shown in Fig. 9. The CO2 decomposition conversion of MgTiO3 with the size range of 0.38 mm-0.83 mm was better than MgTiO3 with the size range of 0.16 mm-0.18 mm. The energy efficiency also increased gradually because the CO2 flow rate increased from 20 mL/min to 100 mL/min. The size of the packing materials could affect the plasma discharge characteristic, which would affect the CO2 decomposition in a plasma reactor [31]. 3.2.3 Effect of discharge power on CO2 decomposition As shown in Fig. 10, the influence of discharge power modulation on CO2 conversion and energy efficiency was studied when MgTiO3 was used as catalyst. With increasing input power, discharge intensity of reactor enhanced obviously at feed flow rate of 20 mL/min. The filamentary discharge could be clearly observed on the edge of the reactor that produced more high energy electrons and radicals which resulted in a larger chance of CO2 collision dissociation and a higher conversion of CO2. The CO2 conversion increased from 3.4 % to 23 % together with increasing discharge power from 10 W to 90 W and CO2 conversion reached 22.8 % under power of 60 W (SEI = 180 kJ/L). The energy efficiency of CO2 decomposition didn’t show a monotonous growth trend because there existed a maximum ratio of CO2 conversion and discharge power when the power increased from 10 W to 90 W. The maximum energy efficiency was 2.1 % at 30 W (SEI = 90 kJ/L). 3.3 Characterization of plasma and catalysts 3.3.1 Discharge current of plasma reactor In the process of dielectric barrier discharge, the micro-discharge current pulse in the reactor can be captured by oscilloscope to reflect the discharge characteristics of plasma. Fig. 11 shows the change of micro-discharge current pulse when different perovskite catalysts packed in the plasma reactor, in which number and intensity of micro-discharge current pulse was higher than empty reactor. The capacitance of reactor could be changed when perovskite catalysts packed, which caused a transformation of plasma discharge type from filamentary discharge to the combination of filamentary discharge and surface discharge that would enhance the mean intensity of micro-discharge current pulse [28]. Meanwhile, an exorbitant peak current could increase the generation of heat when micro-discharge current pulse reached the level of molecular excitation, which was a negative effect for CO2 energy efficiency. The dielectric constant of SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 is higher than that of MgTiO3 and CaTiO3 [39]. More uniform micro-discharge current pulse generated in reactor could be noticed when SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 packed. The change of the capacitance in reactor finally resulted in a higher CO2 conversion and energy efficiency. 3.3.2 XRD, TEM and SEM analysis Fig. 12 suggests that MgTiO3, CaTiO3, SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 were successfully synthesized by the molten salt method. All of them have a perovskite structure and Debye-Scherrer indicates that the perovskite catalysts synthesized by this method have a large particle size in Table 2 [40]. We can observe from Fig. 13 that only SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 show a single crystal structure. The SEM images in Fig. 14 of the catalysts show that the catalysts have larger diameter. According to TEM and SEM images, different perovskite catalysts had different morphologies. Among them, the MgTiO3 has a larger diameter than CaTiO3, BaTiO3 and SrTiO3 as indicated by data in Table 2. We can observe that only SrTiO3 and MgTiO3 show a single crystalline structure in Fig. 13. The SEM images of catalysts offer further proof of heterogeneous and larger particle diameter in Fig. 14. Since both MgTiO3 and SrTiO3 show better CO2 conversion than the CaTiO3 and BaTiO3, it is reasonable to deduced that the perovskite catalyst with single crystalline structure is beneficial for improving CO2 conversion due to the modified effect on the capacitance of the reactor that makes plasma discharge more uniform. There is no confirmed result was made on the correlation of catalyst particle size and CO2 conversion, while more work needs to be done to make it clear. 3.3.3 BET and CO2-TPD analysis Fig. 15 is N2-adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis of MgTiO3, CaTiO3, SrTiO3 and BaTiO3. It was found that the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of SrTiO3 showed an obvious hysteresis loop and the perovskite catalysts synthesized through the molten salt method had a relatively low pore volume and specific surface area (Table 3 ). The CO2-TPD of catalysts shown in Fig. 16 indicated that the desorption of CO2 occurred at three basic sites: weak-strength basic site, medium-strength basic site (300 °C–700 °C) and strong-strength basic site (Table 4 ) [41,42]. Considering the reaction was carried out at room temperature, we deduced that the weak-strength basic site and medium-strength basic site are more active than the strong-strength basic site for CO2 adsorption and activation. Therefore, both MgTiO3 and SrTiO3 catalysts achieved better CO2 conversion than the other catalysts either with more strong-strength basic site or less weak-strength basic site. 4 Conclusions In this study, the catalytic CO2 decomposition was investigated in an DBD plasma reactor. The effects of internal and external electrode materials on CO2 conversion were carried out. The results indicated that electronic conductivity of the inner material has a positive effect while the thermal conductivity has a negative effect on CO2 conversion. Compared with stainless steel and copper rod, the aluminum rod as internal electrode exhibited better CO2 conversion due to the moderate electronic conductivity and thermal conductivity. As for the outer electrode, copper foil was better than stainless and aluminum material. The synergistic effect of plasma and perovskite on CO2 decomposition was also explored based on characterization results on plasma and catalysts. It was found that the catalysts could modify the capacitance of reactor and adjust the discharge characteristics of the plasma reactor, which enhanced CO2 decomposition and provided an environment in which the catalyst can be activated at low temperature. The perovskite catalyst with single crystalline structure is beneficial for improving CO2 conversion due to the modified effect on the capacitance of the reactor that makes plasma discharge more uniform. The correlation of catalyst particle size and CO2 conversion is not clarified and needs to be further studied. The weak-strength basic site and medium-strength basic site on the catalyst are more active than the strong-strength basic site for CO2 adsorption and activation. coredata.dc:description: Plasma has been widely used in wastewater treatment, material modification and biomedicine due to its unique properties. In this work, a coaxial cylindrical dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor was set up to investigate the effects of electrode materials and catalyst combined with DBD plasma on CO2 decomposition under room temperature and atmosphere pressure. The materials of inner electrode and outer electrode were investigated without catalysts packed in the reactor. It was found that the aluminum rod as inner electrode performed better than copper rod and stainless steel rod due to the moderate thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity of aluminum rod. Nevertheless, copper foil worked better as external electrode material since its higher electrical conductivity facilitated generation of high energy electrons by the high voltage between electrodes. After perovskite-type catalyst was introduced in the reactor, CO2 conversion increased, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of perovskite combined with plasma discharge. Perovskite-type catalysts could modulate the capacitance of the reactor to make plasma discharge more uniform and increased CO2 conversion, while plasma discharge provided high energy electrons that activated oxides sites and basic sites of perovskite-type catalysts. The maximum CO2 conversion was 23 % and maximum energy efficiency was 2.1 % when MgTiO3 was packed in the reactor.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic effect of catalyst and plasma on CO2 decomposition in a dielectric barrier discharge plasma reactor
